abstracts.cdata!:
In the decade following the breakup of
            Yugoslavia, Serbia suffered a near economic meltdown. The
            financial sector was in shambles, and people had little
            confidence in the banking system. Many state-owned companies
            were heavily indebted and lacked adequate corporate
            governance. These problems were combined with hyperinflation
            and high unemployment. The World Bank has helped Serbia
            restructure the banking sector and privatize enterprises to
            foster private sector growth and job creation. Because of
            the interconnectedness of the two sectors, these challenges
            had to be tackled simultaneously. Support was channeled
            through two credits and matched by technical assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro (Formerly Yugoslavia)
            - Private and Financial Sector Structural Adjustment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated highly
            satisfactory, with project sustainability highly likely. The
            overall performance of both the World Bank and the Borrower
            are rated satisfactory. These were some of the lessons
            learned:  Drawing the lessons from Bank's past
            experience is essential. The task team made a particular
            effort to study and apply the right lessons from past
            experience with bank restructuring and enterprise sector
            reform in transition economies, while at the same time
            adjusting it to the special conditions of the borrower with
            the help of the borrower's team. In particular, the
            recognition of the need for a clean and transparent
            privatization process and for tailoring the reform design to
            the specific features and economic culture of the country
            has produced a hard-hitting and results-focused yet
            realistic reform program. The program's sustainability
            derives as much from its technical soundness as from the
            accommodation of societal expectations, and its
            effectiveness is less likely to be marred by the perverse
            distributional and corruption impacts that tainted so many
            of the earlier interventions in some transition economies.
            Transition experience has shown that an integrated approach
            is needed to reform the  enterprise and financial sectors.
            Under the project program, financial sector reforms aim to
            boost financial intermediation, and encourage domestic
            savings, generating the much needed working capital and
            investment finance needed for the real sector to expand. At
            the same time, the privatization of socially-owned
            enterprises and a more vibrant small and medium enterprise
            sector supported by the improved business-enabling
            environment, are expected to lay the basis for sustainable
            growth. Very importantly, the reforms need to be sequenced
            with the government's efforts, to provide adequate
            social protection for those displaced by restructuring and
            privatization. Another key lesson is the need for careful
            sequencing of the more immediate structural reforms in the
            enterprise and financial sector with the long-term efforts
            aimed at creating a modern regulatory and institutional
            framework for sustainable economic growth.  Reform
            implementation is heavily dependent on effective champions.
            It is equally important that reform champions be well
            advised in the actions they do take. The willingness of the
            key actors at the National Bank of Yugoslavia and Ministry
            of Finance and Economy to take dramatic action and close a
            large number of banks enabled key steps forward in the
            restructuring of the banking sector. Similarly, effective
            management of the privatization program facilitated the
            rapid progress in the reform of socially-owned sector. While
            there can be no guarantees of tenure of political
            appointments such as ministers, it is important to have as
            clear a picture as possible of any potential problems.
            Placing qualified and experienced advisers to assist reform
            champions, and providing assistance to educate and
            coordinate across a government may contribute significantly
            to the success of reform efforts. Other lessons point to the
            ability to provide extensive technical assistance on a
            timely basis has been enormously important in enabling the
            PFSAC to achieve its objectives, the benefit of good
            Economic and Sector reporting . (The Country Economic
            Memorandum, "Breaking with the Past," helped the
            government to focus on key reforms, and enabled government
            and the Bank to work together on defining priority reforms
            to be included in this project); and the need to ensure
            sufficient attention is paid to ensuring that the Borrower
            fully understands the fiduciary provisions. Regarding the
            latter, the Bank should provide adequate training and
            support to the borrower during project preparation and
            maintain an active dialogue on fiduciary requirements to
            make certain the credit proceeds are handled properly.

TF026817-PHRD-YUGOSLAVIA: PRIVATE AND

repnme.cdata!:
Federal Republic of yugoslavia (Serbia
            & Montenegro) - Private and Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit (PFSAC) will support the governments of
            the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and its largest
            constituent republic, the Republic of Serbia, in
            implementing financial and enterprise sector reforms seeking
            to significantly accelerate private sector-led-growth
            through: 1) strengthening the financial system by
            liquidating troubled banks and improving the environment
            under which banks operate; 2) privatizing and restructuring
            socially-owned enterprises that crowd out private sector
            growth, hamper banking sector recovery, and incur
            significant fiscal and quasi-fiscal costs; and 3) improving
            the investment climate and business enabling environment.
            Implementation of continued structural reforms will enhance
            Serbia's prospects for growth, and will reinforce the
            sustainability of its macroeconomic stabilization. The main
            benefit of the Credit will be faster private sector growth
            and job creation, supported by a healthier and more
            developed financial system. A significant risk to the PFSAC
            is the global economic downturn that could deter the
            potential private capital inflows to Serbia, affecting the
            success of the tender and auction privatization. Additional
            risks could arise from what is perceived by prospective
            investors as continued political instability in the Balkan region.
